title: Musculoskeletal C&P Exam Preparation Guide
subtitle: Back, Knee, Shoulder, Hip, and Joint Conditions

content.what_exam_assesses: Musculoskeletal C&P exams evaluate conditions affecting your bones, joints, muscles, and connective tissue. This includes injuries and conditions of your spine (neck, upper back, lower back), knees, shoulders, hips, ankles, wrists, elbows, and other joints.
content.why_common: Musculoskeletal conditions are the #1 most claimed disabilities among veterans. Years of carrying heavy gear, physical training, combat stress, and repetitive movements take a toll. The VA knows this—which is why they have detailed procedures for measuring these conditions.

critical_insight.title: Why Accurate Pain Reporting Matters
critical_insight.text: Your rating isn't based on how far you CAN move—it's based on where pain BEGINS. If you can bend your knee to 90 degrees but pain starts at 60 degrees, your rating should be based on 60 degrees. But if you push through the pain and demonstrate 90 degrees, that's what gets documented.
critical_insight.warning: The single biggest mistake veterans make is pushing through pain during ROM tests.

rating_factors: Range of motion (ROM) measured in degrees
Functional loss (what activities you can't do)
Flare-ups (how often your condition gets worse)
Additional factors like weakness, instability, or locking

rom_explanation.title: Range of Motion (ROM)
rom_explanation.text: ROM is measured in degrees using a tool called a goniometer. Each joint has a 'normal' range, and your rating depends on how much motion you've lost compared to normal.

example.principle: The less motion you have, the higher your rating.

pain_on_motion.title: Pain on Motion vs. Pain-Free ROM
pain_on_motion.critical_note: This is critical. The examiner should document TWO things:
measurements: Pain-free ROM: How far you can move WITHOUT pain
Total ROM: How far you can physically move (even with pain)
pain_on_motion.warning: Your rating should consider where pain begins, not just your maximum range. If you push through pain, you're giving the examiner a higher ROM number than you should.

functional_loss.title: Functional Loss
functional_loss.explanation: The VA also rates based on what you CAN'T do because of your condition:
questions: Can you stand for extended periods?
Can you walk without assistance?
Can you lift objects? How heavy?
Does it affect your ability to work?

flare_ups.title: Flare-Ups
flare_ups.explanation: Many conditions have good days and bad days. Flare-ups are periods when your symptoms are significantly worse.
examiner_questions: How much worse is your ROM during flare-ups?
flare_ups.important: Even if you're having a 'good day' at your exam, flare-ups still count toward your rating.

additional_factors: Instability (joint gives way or feels loose)
Use of assistive devices (cane, brace, walker)

content.goniometer_explanation: The examiner uses a goniometer—a protractor-like tool that measures joint angles in degrees. You'll typically perform each movement three times for consistency.

rom_types.description: The examiner moves your joint for you

content.rom_note: Both measurements matter. If passive ROM is greater than active ROM, it may indicate weakness or pain inhibition.

movements.description: Raise arm out to the side
Move leg out to the side

weight_bearing.title: Weight-Bearing vs. Non-Weight-Bearing
weight_bearing.explanation: The examiner should test ROM in both conditions when applicable:
conditions: Weight-bearing: Standing (like you normally use the joint)
weight_bearing.note: Pain may be different in each position. Make sure both are documented.

content.painful_motion_tip: The examiner should note the EXACT degree where pain begins. If they don't ask, TELL THEM: 'My pain starts at about 45 degrees of flexion.'

questions: When did your pain/symptoms start?
What caused the injury or condition?
What treatments have you tried?
Have you had surgery? Physical therapy? Injections?
Where exactly is your pain?
How would you rate your pain on a scale of 1-10?
Is the pain constant or intermittent?
What makes it worse? What makes it better?
How often do you have flare-ups?
How long do they last?
What triggers them?
How bad does it get during a flare-up?
Can you work? What limitations do you have?
How long can you stand? Sit? Walk?
Can you lift objects? How heavy?
Do you use a cane, brace, or other assistive device?
Does it affect your sleep?
What daily activities are difficult or impossible?
What medications do you take?
Do they help? Any side effects?
Have you had imaging (X-ray, MRI)?

two_weeks_before.find_dbq: Search '[joint] DBQ' (e.g., 'knee DBQ' or 'lumbar spine DBQ'). Read it carefully—this is exactly what the examiner fills out. Note the ROM measurements that correspond to different ratings.
two_weeks_before.research_rom: Know what 'normal' is for your joint. Understand that YOUR measurement will be compared to normal. Calculate roughly where your limitation might fall.
document_symptoms: Write down your current ROM limitations (estimate)
List all activities that are difficult or impossible

track_flare_ups: How many flare-ups did you have this month?
How long did each one last?
How limited were you during flare-ups?

examples: I cannot lift more than 10 pounds
I cannot stand for more than 15 minutes
I cannot walk more than one block without stopping
I cannot bend down to tie my shoes

gather_documents: Recent imaging reports (if not already submitted)

clothing: Tank top or loose shirt for shoulder exams
You may be asked to change into a gown
day_before.medication_warning: Take ONLY your normal prescribed dose. Do NOT take extra medication to reduce pain. The exam should reflect your typical condition.

most_important_rule.title: THE MOST IMPORTANT RULE
most_important_rule.instruction: Stop at the point of pain.
most_important_rule.detailed_guidance: When the examiner asks you to bend, flex, or rotate a joint: Move until you feel pain, STOP at that point, and tell the examiner: 'This is where my pain starts.'
do_not: Push through pain to show you can go further
Try to impress the examiner with your toughness
Let the examiner push your joint past where pain begins

why_it_matters.scenario: If you can flex your knee to 90 degrees but pain begins at 60 degrees:

outcomes.documented: Flexion limited to 60° due to pain

why_it_matters.key_point: 'Painful motion' is a legitimate limitation. The VA recognizes this. But you have to COMMUNICATE it.

during_rom_testing: I can only bend to here before pain stops me
This is my pain-free range of motion
If I go further, the pain becomes severe
On bad days, I can't even get this far
about_flare_ups: Today is actually a better day. During flare-ups, I can barely move
My ROM is about 50% worse during flare-ups
I have flare-ups 3-4 times per month lasting 2-3 days each
about_function: I can't stand long enough to cook dinner
I had to quit my job because I couldn't lift anymore
I need my wife to help me put on socks

mistakes.description: This is the most damaging mistake veterans make. You've been trained to push through pain. In this exam, that training works against you.
mistakes.what_happens: You bend your knee until it really hurts (let's say 50°), but you keep pushing to show you can reach 90°. Examiner documents 'knee flexion to 90 degrees.' Your rating is based on 90°, not 50°.
mistakes.fix: STOP where pain begins. That's your real, functional limit.

mistakes.description: Taking more than your normal dose masks your symptoms. The examiner sees a medicated version of your condition, not your typical experience.
Even if today is a good day, your worst days matter. If you don't mention flare-ups, they won't be documented.
The examiner can measure your ROM, but they can't know that you can't tie your shoes or that you had to stop working. TELL THEM.
Tight jeans or restrictive shirts can limit your movement during testing, making your ROM appear better than it is. Wear loose clothing.
If the examiner doesn't ask where pain begins, volunteer the information: 'I should mention—my pain-free range is only about 45 degrees. I can push further, but that's where the pain starts.'

document_immediately.instruction: As soon as you leave, write down:
items: Whether the examiner pushed past your pain point
Anything that felt rushed or incomplete

red_flags: Examiner pushed your joint past your pain point

request_results.instruction: You can get a copy of your completed DBQ:
request_results.check: Check the measurements. If your ROM is documented as higher than what you demonstrated, or if painful motion isn't noted, you have grounds to challenge.

before_rating_decision: Submit a written statement describing the exam issues
after_unfavorable_rating: File a Supplemental Claim with new evidence
Get a private medical opinion with accurate ROM measurements

content.timeline: Rating decisions typically arrive 60-90 days after your exam. Check your status regularly on VA.gov.

key_takeaways: Stop at the pain point during ROM testing
Communicate clearly about where pain begins
Describe your worst days, not just today
Don't take extra pain medication before the exam
Document functional limitations in specific terms

closing_message.text: Your body has been through a lot in service. This exam is your chance to show exactly how those injuries affect you now.

preparation_checklist.task: Find and read the DBQ form for your specific joint condition
Research normal ROM ranges for your joint (know what 'normal' degrees are)
Understand the rating criteria (what ROM limitations equal which percentages)
Document your current symptoms and estimated ROM limitations
Track and document flare-ups (frequency, duration, triggers, severity)
Write specific functional limitation statements (can't lift >10 lbs, can't stand >15 min)
List all daily activities that are difficult or impossible due to condition
Gather recent imaging reports (X-ray, MRI) if not already submitted
List all medications with dosages and side effects
Document any assistive devices you use (brace, cane, walker)
Prepare loose, comfortable clothing for the exam
Confirm exam date, time, and location
Take ONLY normal medication dose (do NOT take extra pain meds)
Practice saying 'This is where my pain starts' and 'Please stop, that hurts'
Bring written notes, ID, medication list, and any assistive devices
